Reviewed by Aeronaut, callforjudgement, Cheery Dog

Spoiler:

Dead Players:
Spoiler:
Katsuki, Town Roleblocker, lynched Day 1
xyzzy, Vanilla Townie, killed Night 1
implosion, Vanilla Townie, lynched Day 2
kagesong I Am Innocent, Town Neapolitan, killed Night 2
drmyshottyizsik, Mafia Goon, lynched Day 3
Thestatusquo, Vanilla Townie, killed Night 3

Kmd4390, Vanilla Townie, lynched Day 5
SnarkySnowman, Town Rolestopper, killed Night 5
MagnaofIllusion DrippingGoofball, Town Neighborizer, killed Night 6
Creature, Vanilla Townie, lynched Day 7
BlueBloodedToffee Aristophanes, Vanilla Townie, endgamed

The Rules:
1. All site rules apply.
2. Be nice. Mafia games can get heated but remember never to attack the person.
3. Play to your wincon.
4. Days are approximately 14 days long, nights are approximately 48 hours long. Extensions may be given the circumstances warrant it.
5. Failure to post at least once every 48 hours will result in a prod. If you do not pick up your prod in 24 hours, or if I have to prod you a third time, I will look for a replacement.
6. Please put votes in this format: VOTE: Something_Smart. Technically, bolded votes are allowed (Vote: Something_Smart), but they are a lot harder to see. It's easier for you and easier for me. In case you don't know, you can vote with:
Code: Select all
[vote]Something_Smart[/vote]

and unvote with
Code: Select all
[unvote][/unvote]

Unvotes are not necessary to change your vote.
7. If more than half the players are voting for a player, then that player is lynched and removed from the game, and the day will end. If the deadline is reached before a lynch occurs, the day will end without a lynch.
8. If you have a question for me, put it in bold and say @Mod or @Something_Smart. If it's not something you want made public, feel free to shoot me a PM.
9. This lovely shade of yellow (#FFBF00) is the mod color. Do not use it. Do not impersonate me.
10. Do not discuss this game in any other thread except in PTs created specifically for this game. Do not discuss any other ongoing game in this thread.
11. Do not quote any out-of-thread communications with me or with any other player.
12. The day after you are lynched or nightkilled, you may make one "bah!" post with no game-related information in it.
13. Do not pretend to break any of these rules. Pretending to break a rule is punishable just as harshly as actually breaking it.
14. My word is law. Just because it is not stated here does not mean that it is acceptable. I am generally a nice person and will give you a warning if you do something I don't approve of, but it's always better to ask than risk the consequences (see rule 8).
15. This game is 3 mafia-aligned players versus 10 town-aligned players.
16. This game follows the Normal Guidelines. At least one player has the following role PM:
Welcome, XXXX, to Mini 1786: Inspirational Mafia!

You are a Vanilla Townie.
You have no special abilities. Your weapons are your mind and your vote.
You win when all anti-town factions have been eliminated and at least one town-aligned player is alive.

Please respond to this PM indicating you understand your role and your win condition.

The game thread is here.

Role PMs are out! The game will begin when 11/13 have confirmed.

Confirmed: Everybody!

12/13 have confirmed! Day 1 begins now!

You only live once, but if you do it right, once is enough.

Congrats. You just fell for one of my favorite trap scum tells. It's called the "deliberately weak argument." How it works is you make an argument and then somewhere in there you throw in a point that is deliberately bad. Easy to refute. It's a motivation tell to determine if someone is arguing in good faith or not. See, town players tend to address the argument in its entirety, because they want to evaluate the argument and they are interested in determining the alignment of the person making it. Scum, however, don't care about that. They are just arguing to score points. They go directly for the deliberately weak argument and attack it, and avoid the rest of the argument entirely.

You want to know which pattern describes what you just did?

I'll give you a hint. It starts with Sc. And ends with Umfucker.

Playtime is over.

I'm voting you for (now) 5 reasons.

1) I felt that your question to kage was setting up an attack on a newer player. I really didn't like the line of questioning on that slot in particular which is why I then attacked you for asking it. Your response to me didn't help, as you refused to answer my question and attacked me for "answering your question for him" which I didn't do. I never answered your question. I attacked you for asking it.

2) I feel like your tone with regards to yourself is wildly different from how you are interacting with other players. You want other people to be accountable for the things they do in thread, which is great, but you don't seem to want to hold yourself to the same standard. You continued to joke vote MoI while attacking other players for not being serious enough. You joke fake claimed. Basically it looked like you were trying to attack players for serious things while, when people called your behavior into question for similar reasons you basically were like "oh come on its still RVS"

3) One of the main things I look for in scum reading is what are the motivations of players when they're arguing with you. I wrote a whole long treatise about this in mafia discussion a long time ago. I think there is a fundamental difference in the way that town players and scum players argue. Town players tend to grant the possibility that the person they are arguing with is town, while scum players do not. This leads to different kinds of arguments. A town argument typically involves things like addressing all (or at least most) of the points, conceding arguments that they agree with, looking for other things about the player which are relevant. That is because town are interested in alignment. Scum are not, when they argue it typically looks like someone trying to score points in a debate. They attack weak arguments. They don't give credence to good points. They just simply point and try to make the other person look like an idiot because that makes them look like the "winner" of the argument. I feel like your arguing style much more closely aligns with this second pattern in the game then it does the first.

4) More to the point, you fell for a motivation tell that I deliberately threw out there to see who would attack it. You argued not in order to discern my alignment, but rather you attempted to discredit me by going for the low hanging fruit of the deliberately weak argument.

5) Your refusal to seriously claim is deliberately anti town because you're upset. Town refusing to claim (and fake claiming) when they're at l-1 hurts town in general. If you are town, I suggest you cut it out immediately. More importantly, I've seen town use this tactic far less than scum, in the hopes that the refusal to claim will diffuse the bandwagon.


Hope that helps!

Congrats. You just fell for one of my favorite trap scum tells. It's called the "deliberately weak argument." How it works is you make an argument and then somewhere in there you throw in a point that is deliberately bad. Easy to refute. See, town players tend to address the argument in its entirety, because they want to evaluate the argument and they are interested in determining the alignment of the person making it. Scum, however, don't care about that. They are just arguing to score points. They go directly for the deliberately weak argument and attack it, and avoid the rest of the argument entirely.

[quote="MoI]
There is no such thing as “flip agnostic analysis” that is scum-hunting. Because there is no way to actually get a read from a vote that is independent of alignment IMO.[/quote]
Disagree. You can read player x as townish for their vote on player y in a vacuum regardless of player y's alignment. In fact the only way it even makes sense in such a case that player x's alignment is predicated on player y's alignment is because of conditional probabilities. Apart from that, if player x is town, then player x is going to make the same arguments towards player y whether player y is actually town or actually scum; it's just a matter of what player x is perceiving player y to be. Therefore we have to read the vote in a vacuum to some degree. But overall this is a somewhat moot point because like some of the other arguments I've made it doesn't matter if you don't think you can get a read from a vote that is independent of alignment because other players (i.e. Creature) may believe that they can. There's no way (or at least it seems extremely unlikely) that two scum would conspire together to both townslip. I just don't see that being a likely thing that scum would decide to do in a game like this where I think there is probably the impression that most of the player list is going to be highly skeptical of townslips and the like (although I am less skeptical than most people). Opinions on the setup? I was one of the setup reviewers, and want to know whether I did a good job here.

In particular, this setup has something of a Stoofer's Third Law element going on. Town have quite a few moderately powerful power roles, and would be overpowered if all their roles worked at their full potential, but that's balanced by the potential for them to trip over each other (something that I felt was happening while reading through the game). This is something I don't see that often in Mini Normals all that much, so it made the setup interesting to review. (It's also interesting to notice that the setup started in quite a different place and morphed into this one over time.)

In case anyone is interested, the review thread is here.

I think it was hard to guage. There were 2 times in which a confTown or investigative died when they really should have been rolestopped. So I think that it was good the game felt scumsided. I think it errs a little more towards town but its hard to judge based on this game.
in a vacuum this setup was townsided. it's not enough to be an issue though so I wouldn't worry about it.

Our philosophy was, with proper play (neapolitan claims early and is protected) the setup is a little townsided, but I figured that it would take time for the town to figure that out (actually kage claiming D2 could have been really strong for town if Snarky had protected the right people).

Also, the neapolitan cannot get confirmed guilties and can end up outing town PR's (Stoofer's Third Law), and with the neapolitan and the rolecop both searching for the protective it shouldn't take too long to find it, plus the scum can just kill off the confirmed innocents in the process, plus both the roleblocker and neighborizer can become suspected if they claim.

Overall we figured the townsidedness of the setup would be balanced out by its awkwardness and lack of confirmability. Which turned out to be a non-issue except for ironically the neighborizer being confirmed town for being too weak to be a scum role.
I would have gotten absolutely rolled if the PRs had been playing even a little more effectively though

Congrats to the Mafia!
